awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Deposition and Interface Properties of Metal Oxide Films on GaAs
awd_abstract_narration:
Technical: This project aims to produce fundamental knowledge about the molecular level mechanisms of atomic layer deposition (ALD). In particular, atomic layer deposition of metal oxide films from alkyl amide precursors and water on GaAs surfaces is studied. GaAs due to its intriguing surface chemistry provides a suitable system to test and further our understanding of the molecular level mechanisms and kinetic processes involved in the atomic layer deposition process. Furthermore, its increasing technological importance make such as study very timely as it aims to bridge a gap of fundamental knowledge in the literature. A comprehensive approach that includes both in-situ monitoring of the surface chemistry using infrared spectroscopy as well as extensive ex-situ analysis of the materials and interface properties is used during the research project.
Non-technical: The project addresses basic research issues in a topical area of materials science with high technological relevance. Graduate students from diverse backgrounds are trained in an interdisciplinary field, and a much needed interdisciplinary laboratory course in materials characterization is introduced to complement an existing lecture course in the physics of surfaces and interfaces. Undergraduate students from disadvantaged backgrounds, as well as participants of the McNair program at the University of Maryland Baltimore County, are mentored during a summer research program with the goal to encourage their interest in scientific careers.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The transistor which constitutes the building block of modern technology is a structure that includes several thin layers of materials. The ability to form these layered structures with high precision in regards to its dimension and accuracy in regards to its properties is critical. In this project we studied the formation of ultra-thin insulating (dielectric) layers on compound semiconductor surfaces such as GaAs and InAs. These semiconductors offer several key advantages over Si and are under intense study for future generation of electronics. We have used a technique called atomic layer deposition (ALD) that allows formation of films one layer at a time and allows unprecedented control over the film thickness and properties. Film formation is accomplished by a chemical reaction between the two reactants introduced sequentially and suitable chemical groups bonded on the surface. Understanding this reaction mechanism as well as the effect of parameters such as temperature and surface preparation is critical is obtaining high quality films and consequently devices.

In our work we have used a combination of in situ and ex situ techniques to study the formation and evolution of the interface between the compound semiconductor and the insulating film. We verified that for alkyl amide metal organic precursors interaction of the precursor with the semiconductor surface native oxides leads to the formation of a sharp interface. This interaction persists even after the surface has been completely covered by several monolayers of the deposited film.  To resolve this apparent paradox we have designed a series of experiments that confirm the existence of a new, unacknowledged mechanism: the semiconductor native oxides transport to the surface of the deposited film making possible continuous interaction with the precursor. Since different materials have varying diffusion blocking properties, this observation can explain some of the conflicting literature observations. We have also confirmed the existence of other surface reaction mechanisms in addition to the simple ligand exchange mechanism such as precursor dissociation and formation of secondary species. According to recent computational studies this step is required to explain the confirmed through multiple observation reaction of the precursor with the surface native oxides.  Having the ability to produce high quality dielectric (insulating) films on a variety of surfaces allowed us to provide such films for high electron mobility transistors at Naval Research Laboratory leading to the formation of high quality devices as documented in a series of publications.

All of the results have been made available to the broader scientific community through peer review publications and conference presentations. In addition to the pure scientific value, our results are important to the semiconductor industry as they elucidate the ALD mechanism as well as highlight the complexity of the surface chemistry. Despite this complexity though once the various mechanisms are recognized this knowledge can be leveraged to produce materials with desired properties.  In addition to the technological implications of our work, this grant provided support for two graduate students. One has already graduated and accepted a position with a leading company in the area of energy and the other is scheduled to graduate in December 2015.  Several undergraduate students were also given the opportunity to participate in the research activities. One of these students has chosen to serve as science teacher in the Maryland Public School System. This is critically important for the STEM education in Maryland and the US in general as there are not enough qualified individuals with degrees in Physics that chose teaching as a career pa...
